Ryan et al -
Many an uneducated swordsm=
an has, and many still do. The key is of
course recognition. Do many people=
 recognize your style as having
practical, spiritual and cultural value, en=
ough that your style will
continue long after your passing. Do otherwise un=
iterested parties
recognize what you are doing as Japanese Swordsmanship or=
 at least
swordsmanship. Finally does the pioneer himself recognize the
con=
tributions of past masters, and that it takes really big cahones to
pronoun=
ce to the world they have broken with tradition and started his
own way and=
 how that might rub folks the wrong way no matter how good
or how logical h=
is new style may be.

you might go to the Iaido/l list at the University of=
 Guelph, or
swordforum.com for some other opinions.

You didn't ask but, my=
 advice would be to align yourself with an
establish tradition, then work h=
ard and if you're lucky enough, open
your own dojo. You get to teach what y=
ou like and you're students will
be part of something bigger than the backy=
ard Ryuha. and for goodness
sakes if you aren't Japanese don't give it a Ja=
panese name...
MHO
